msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: William Lewis Sharkey served as Mississippi’s governor in 1865, early in the Reconstruction era.

Born in Sumner County, Tennessee, on July 12, 1798, Sharkey moved with his family to Warren County, Mississippi, in 1804. As an adult, he studied law and began practicing in Natchez, Mississippi, in 1822. Sharkey moved to Vicksburg in 1825 and pursued political office. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served one term from 1828 to 1829.

In 1832, Sharkey married Minerva Cage, a widow with two children. The couple had four children over the next several years. In 1832, Sharkey also became a circuit court judge and was shortly thereafter elected to the High Court of Errors and Appeals, the predecessor to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. He served in that role for 18 years, resigning in 1851. From there, he took a diplomatic appointment for the United States government, serving as U.S. Consul in Havana, Cuba, until 1854. After completing that diplomatic assignment, Sharkey returned to Mississippi and returned to legal and political duties, helping compile the Mississippi Code of 1857.

During the secession crisis in the winter of 1860 and 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election, Sharkey remained a steadfast Unionist. Having been a member of the Whig Party, he retained his opposition to secession and refused to support the Confederacy, even as he remained in Mississippi through the Civil War. Despite his political stance against Mississippi’s secessionist government, Confederate officials left him alone out of respect of his past service to the state as a judge and legal scholar.

After the Confederacy’s defeat, President Andrew Johnson appointed Sharkey provisional governor of Mississippi in June 1865. In that role, he called forth a constitutional convention to meet Johnson’s goal of swiftly restoring former Confederate states to the Union. In October 1865, Benjamin Humphreys won election as Mississippi’s governor. Sharkey did not vacate the office, though, until December 1865, having served less than a year. Although no longer governor, Sharkey was selected by the Mississippi legislature to serve in the U.S. Senate. Federal officials denied him a seat, and the rest of the Mississippi congressional delegation, following the Republican backlash to Mississippi’s Black Codes—a set of racially discriminatory laws passed by the Mississippi legislature in 1865.

Having been denied a U.S. Senate seat, Sharkey returned to practicing law, in Jackson, Mississippi. He died in Washington, D.C., on March 30, 1873, and is buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “William Lewis Sharkey: Twenty-fifth Governor of Mississippi: June to December 1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)

note.p: Charles Edward Smedes was an attorney, businessman, and Confederate officer in Mississippi.

Born in 1824 in New York, Smedes moved to Mississippi as a young man. He studied law and briefly worked as an attorney, but found greater interest and success in grocery sales. In 1846, when the Mexican-American War began, he volunteered for military service and served in the Mississippi Rifles under future Confederate president Jefferson Davis. After that war, he operated a wholesale grocery business in Vicksburg, Mississippi.

When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Smedes was commissioned an officer in the Mississippi state troops. He was appointed brigadier general in 1862 in command of the Third Brigade, Mississippi Minute Men. After the Civil War, Smedes worked with his brother in the cotton firm George Smedes & Company, based in New Orleans, Louisiana. Later, he became the proprietor of the St. James Hotel in New Orleans, a venture that proved extremely profitable and led to his association with several other high-end hotels and resorts, including the Maxwell House in Nashville, Tennessee, the Marnes Hotel, in Mississippi City, Mississippi, and the Planters’ House in Augusta, Georgia. In 1878, he took over the Barnes Hotel in Mississippi City and renovated it into the new Gulf View hotel, which became one of the most popular resorts in the south.
He was married twice, first to Martha Brodnax. He later married Sophie Sibley. Smedes had at least five children. Smedes died in November 1898 in Louisia.
(The Biloxi Herald, Biloxi, MS, November 19, 1898; FindaGrave; “Mississippi Minute Men,” Carroll County MSGenWeb Project; Biographical and Historical Memoirs of Mississippi, Vol. II, 788)
Charles Edward Smedes belonged to the following social groups:

Currently located in Claiborne County, Rocky Springs was settled in 1796 and became part of Mississippi Territory on April 6, 1798. On April 1, 1799, it became part of the newly created Pickering County (which was renamed Jefferson County on January 10, 1802) until the creation of Claiborne County on January 26, 1802. Rocky Springs is a deserted town with few or no remaining inhabitants. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

Located in Warren County, Mississippi, Vicksburg was founded under the name Fort Nogales as early as 1790 in what was then unincorporated territory. In 1798, upon creation of Mississippi Territory, it was renamed Walnut Hills. On April 1, 1799, Walnut Hills became part of the newly created Pickering County (later renamed Jefferson County on January 10, 1802), until the creation of Claiborne County on January 26, 1802. It then became part of its current county of Warren on December 21, 1809. Upon its incorporation on January 29th, 1825, it was renamed Vicksburg. Vicksburg became the county seat in 1836 and remains today. (Rowland, Mississippi, 858; Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "The act of officially choosing someone for a job, or the job itself." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A member of the police force." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Sharkey at Jackson, Mississippi, asking that Sharkey appoint D. A. Parker justice of the peace for the 3rd police district of Claiborne County, Mississippi.

div.p: In accordance with the request of the citizens of Police district No 3 of Claiborne County expressed at a meeting of them on yester-day at Rocky Springs. I write you this note, asking that you will if consistent with your views of propriety appoint a Justice of the Peace for said district at your earli-est convinience and rec-commend for said appoint-ment the name of D. A. J. Parker The unsettled condition of things makes it necessary that we should have such an officer at this time.—The more espe-cially, now, that the citizens have taken steps to organise a patrol to try and correct the state of lawlessness that
that exists in our county and bring back repose, and order.
Your favorable action on the above request will confer a favor upon our County and people.
And much oblige your obdt Svt

Gov Wm L Sharkey
Jackson
Mis

P. S. Do me the favor to write me at once on the subject
Care of Brooke & Smedes
Vicksburg

D. A. J. Parker
I Ref Beat no 3 Claiborne County issued—
